Speaker.hpid: Mr. White Mr. White Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: and Mr. White asked the Minister for Energy if his attention has been drawn to the deep concern of local residents in the Fintown area of County Donegal regarding the proposed uranium mining and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Colley) George Colley
Speaker.P: I am aware of the concern of local residents in the Fintown area of County Donegal at the possibility of uranium mining in the area.

The question of actual mining of uranium in the area does not arise at the present time. Under a licence granted by my Department, a minerals exploration company is engaged in a prospecting programme aimed at establishing the minerals potential of the areas licensed to them in the vicinity of Fintown. Whilst the company has reported positive indications of uranium presence, its work is at a relatively early stage and no firm conclusions can be drawn at present about the prospects of a deposit of commercial proportions being delineated. The licence does not authorise the company to carry out mining operations.

MainHeading.P: If a commercial deposit is established it will be necessary for a prospective mine operator to secure planning permission from the local planning authority, to obtain a mining lease or licence from my Department and to secure a licence from the Nuclear Energy Board. Before any mining operation could commence, the appropriate authorities would have to be fully satisfied in regard to impact of mining operations on public health and the environment and other aspects of public concern. The adequacy of existing statutory requirements in the interests of public health and protection of the environment will be kept under review and, if necessary, they will be supplemented.

The Nuclear Energy Board, the statutory authority in Ireland in relation to radioactive substances, has advised me that there is no evidence that prospecting operations in the Fintown area, or elsewhere in the country, lead to any radiation hazard. The board is keeping in close touch with prospecting activity in the area and has initiated a programme of measurement of any radioactivity in air, water and soil in the area. Furthermore, to ensure adequate consultation between my Department, the board and other bodies with public responsibility in relation to uranium prospecting, I am setting up a working group under the chairmanship of a senior officer of my Department which will keep prospecting activity in the area under regular review.

Speaker.P: Slaughtering premises catering for the export market are governed by the Agricultural Produce (Fresh Meat) Acts and certain EEC legislation and operate under the supervision of my Department. Usually the standards required for export premises reflect the requirements of importing countries. Premises catering for the home market are governed by the Public Health Acts and are the responsibility of the local authority concerned.

asked the Minister for Agriculture if any analysis has been made of the reason for the classification of farmers as transitional who are not capable of reaching the comparable income under the farm modernisation scheme, and if so, if he will outline the details of the findings.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: The classification of applicants under the farm modernisation scheme is determined in accordance with objective criteria laid down in Directive 72/159/EEC on which the scheme is based. So called “transitional” farmers—the correct designation is “other”—are those applicants whose farming circumstances are such that they cannot undertake development plans capable of achieving the comparable income at the end of the stipulated six-year period—eight years in the Disadvantaged Areas.
The main reasons why many farms cannot generate the comparable income at the end of this period include size, quality of holding, choice of farm enterprise and family circumstances.

These farmers still quality, of course, for grant-aid for basic investment under the scheme and, through such basic investment, may eventually move into the “development” category through a process of re-assessment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Food Hygiene and Quality.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he received any report from inspectors on the hygiene and nutritional quality of food on sale in retail outlets, the form of these reports and if they disclose an improvement in recent years in food hygiene and quality.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The reports from health inspectors on the hygiene and quality of foodstuffs are in the normal course submitted to health boards and not to my Department. Where, however, there might be a general risk to health, for example from a particular foodstuff, a report would be furnished to my Department.

As part of the food law enforcement programme of the health boards, samples of food taken from retail outlets are analysed by public analysts on a routine basis for contamination and adulteration, factors which would influence nutritional quality. Summaries of the results of these analyses are furnished to my Department each year by public analysts. These summaries show that only a small proportion of samples tested are found to be unsatisfactory.

In the course of the national hygiene campaign health boards were required to intensify their activities in the inspections of food premises and I am satisfied that this has resulted in a general improvement in standards of food hygiene and quality.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sale of Cyclamate.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if cyclamates are carcinogenic and if they are on sale here for any purpose.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Experiments on rodents fed with cyclamate, which were carried out in 1969, indicated that the substance was possibly carcinogenic. However, further experiments carried out on rodents in recent years have cast doubts on the results of the earlier work. There is no evidence to show that cyclamate is carcinogenic in other species, including man.

MainHeading.P: Cyclamate is used in the manufacture of some medicines which are on sale in this country.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Means Assessment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: and Mr. Boland asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason free board and lodging is assessed as means in claims for single women's allowance but not assessed in claims for non-contributory old age pension.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The reason free board and lodging is assessed as means in claims for single woman's allowance is that means assessment for that allowance is similar to that applied to unemployment assistance which requires the assessment of free board and lodging.

MainHeading.P: The scheme of social assistance allowances for single women was introduced to cover a need which was not being covered adequately by the unemployment assistance scheme and it was considered appropriate to apply the same criteria for means assessment to it as applied to unemployment assistance. The same considerations do not apply in the case of non-contributory old age pension the means test for which is designed to meet the needs of persons aged 66 or over and differs in several respects from that applicable to unemployed persons.
